oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Candida albicans Hyphae: From Growth Initiation to Invasion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Desai, Jigar V
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Candida albicans
invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Candida albicans is a commensal resident of the human gastrointestinal and genital tracts. Under conditions such as dysbiosis, host immune perturbances, or the presence of catheters/implanted medical devices, the fungus may cause debilitating mucosal or fatal systemic infections. The ability of C. albicans to grow as long filamentous hyphae is critical for its pathogenic potential as it allows the fungus to invade the underlying substratum. In this brief review, I will outline the current understanding regarding the mechanistic regulation of hyphal growth and invasion in C. albicans.
